name: Route
comment: route-client.Route represents a node in the route tree.

dontLeaveOnParamChanges.name: dontLeaveOnParamChanges
dontLeaveOnParamChanges.comment: Whether to trigger the leave event when only the parameters change.

isActive.name: isActive
isActive.comment: Indicates whether this route is currently active. Root route is always active.

name.name: name
name.comment: Name of the route. Used when querying routes.

onEnter.name: onEnter
onEnter.comment: Returns a stream of route-client.RouteEnterEvent events. The route-client.RouteEnterEvent event is fired when route has already been made active, but before subroutes are entered. The event starts at the root and propagates from parent to child routes.

onLeave.name: onLeave
onLeave.comment:
Returns a stream of route-client.RouteLeaveEvent events. The route-client.RouteLeaveEvent event is fired when the route is being left. The event starts at the leaf route and propagates from child to parent routes.

At this stage it's possible to veto leaving of the route by calling route-client.RouteLeaveEvent.allowLeave with a dart-async.Future returns a boolean value indicating whether leave is permitted (true) or not (false).

Note: that once child routes have been notified of the leave they will not be notified of the subsequent veto by any parent route. See: https://github.com/angular/route.dart/issues/28

onPreEnter.name: onPreEnter
onPreEnter.comment:
Returns a stream of route-client.RoutePreEnterEvent events. The route-client.RoutePreEnterEvent event is fired when the route is matched during the routing, but before any previous routes were left, or any new routes were entered. The event starts at the root and propagates from parent to child routes.

At this stage it's possible to veto entering of the route by calling route-client.RoutePreEnterEvent.allowEnter with a dart-async.Future returns a boolean value indicating whether enter is permitted (true) or not (false).

onRoute.name: onRoute
onRoute.comment: Returns a stream of route-client.RouteEnterEvent events. The route-client.RouteEnterEvent event is fired when route has already been made active, but before subroutes are entered. The event starts at the root and propagates from parent to child routes.

parameters.name: parameters
parameters.comment: Returns parameters for the currently active route. If the route is not active the getter returns null.

findRoute.name: findRoute
findRoute.comment:
Queries sub-routes using the route-client.Route.findRoute.routePath and returns the matching route-client.Route.

route-client.Route.findRoute.routePath is a dot-separated list of route names. Ex: foo.bar.baz, which means that current route should contain route named 'foo', the 'foo' route should contain route named 'bar', and so on.

If no match is found then null is returned.

getRoute.name: getRoute
getRoute.comment:
Queries sub-routes using the route-client.Route.getRoute.routePath and returns the matching route-client.Route.

route-client.Route.getRoute.routePath is a dot-separated list of route names. Ex: foo.bar.baz, which means that current route should contain route named 'foo', the 'foo' route should contain route named 'bar', and so on.

If no match is found then null is returned.

newHandle.name: newHandle
newHandle.comment: Create an return a new route-client.RouteHandle for this route.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides route-client.Route.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and route-client.Route.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the route-client.Route.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
route-client.Route.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to route-client.Route.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If route-client.Route.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of route-client.Route.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.
